sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for Ǧīm

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
The given source Owens 1984b does not provide any info about ǧ in JOR-BDL.
The given source Palva1986 does not provide any info about ǧ in JOR-HWT.
The given source Yrttiaho1988 does not provide any info about ǧ in JOR-NMT.
The given source Palva1974 does not provide any info about ǧ in JOR-SFT.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Only attested in the eastern quarter of Haifa ḥallīṣa populated by a mixture of refugees from the southern Carmel and immigrants from other areas such as Nablus who arrived in 1930
More frequent than ǧ
Less frequent than ž
Speakers of ṣaffūri only have this reflex
There is desaffrication when in contact with coronal consonants
Speakers from ʕArab əl Maslax show both ǧ and ž with a higher tendency to use ǧ by older speakers and within conversations related to Bedouin lifestyle and traditions
Speakers from ʕArab əl Maslax show variation between ǧ and ž. The use of ž is predominant among young speakers
not phonologically conditioned, but related to origin and gender of the speaker
VERIFY SOURCE
not phonologically conditioned, but related to origin and gender of the speaker
VERIFY SOURCE
The most frequent reflex of ǧīm is ǧ, but [gy], which is often difficult to distinguish from [g], also occurs. The reflex of ǧīm in BṢ is a very intricate problem.
Cantineau affirms ǧ is the general trend but the pronounciation of ǧ tends to evolve to /ž/
no ex
value taken from text, feature does not have a specific section in the description
We also find ǧa - yīǧi to come, el-ʕeǧel veal
y becomes i when not follwed by a vowel
žēš "army", šažara "tree", bižūz "it is possible"
rarely ž (no ex.)
it can also be ž or dy
no ex in text for this feature
Cantineau does not give ex. but says he confirms what Montagne wrote in his texts which were expected to be published soon after in the same year (always in 1936)
ḥčara stone
no ex
it has 2 values: gy and g
1 ex of dy: dymoli my camel
retained in neologisms, cultural words and classical contexts
in final pausal positions
in contact positions before a voiceless phoneme
in contact positions before a voiced consonant
The range of palatization goes from ɟ to j.
The range of palatization goes from ɟ to j.
In free variation with ž.
In free variation with ǧ.
In this dialect, also *z is reflected as /ź/, e.g. xbəź "he baked"
only presumably
In the article there is also one word with /ǧ/, ǧārek "your neighbour" (p.10)
/ğ/ is also heard, especially after a dental /n/, e.g.fenğāl ‘glass’
Assimilation: ʕaǧūza > ʕžūza „mother -in-law‟

"On the other hand, I found three examples where classical /ǧ/ undergoes dissimilation to /d/ when preceded or followed by a sibilant: CA zuǧāǧun >zdāž „glass‟10, CA al-ǧazāʔiru >Dzāyəṛ „Algiers‟ 11, CA ǧāsirun >dāsəṛ „insolent, rude‟. It must be highlighted that in OA this dissimilation is not as common as it isin Moroccan dialects where classical /ǧ/ is almost always pronounced /d/ or /g/ in contact with sibilant phonemes"
When the ž is in contact with a subsequent voiceless, it is reflected as š e.g. zouštah 'his wife'
geminated > ǧ d-ǧamaʕ mosque, sometimes in contact with r > ǧ: yxurǧu 'they go out'
most frequent realisation
